sn3.1:1.2: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.
sn3.1:1.3: Then King Pasenadi of Kosala went up to the Buddha, and exchanged greetings with him.
sn3.1:1.4: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, he sat down to one side and said to the Buddha,
sn3.1:1.5: “Does Master Gotama claim to have awakened to the supreme perfect awakening?”
sn3.1:1.6: “If anyone should rightly be said to have awakened to the supreme perfect awakening, it’s me.
sn3.1:1.7: For, great king, I have awakened to the supreme perfect awakening.”
sn3.1:2.1: “Well, there are those ascetics and brahmins who lead an order and a community, and teach a community. They’re well-known and famous religious founders, regarded as holy by many people. That is,
sn3.1:2.2: Pūraṇa Kassapa, Makkhali Gosāla, Nigaṇṭha Nāṭaputta, Sañjaya Belaṭṭhiputta, Pakudha Kaccāyana, and Ajita Kesakambala.
sn3.1:2.3: I also asked them whether they claimed to have awakened to the supreme perfect awakening, but they made no such claim.
sn3.1:2.4: So why do you, given that you’re so young in age and newly gone forth?”
sn3.1:3.1: “Great king, these four things should not be looked down upon or disparaged because they are young.
sn3.1:3.7: These four things should not be looked down upon or disparaged because they are young.”
sn3.1:4.1: That is what the Buddha said.
sn3.1:4.2: Then the Holy One, the Teacher, went on to say:
sn3.1:6.1: For it’s possible that that lord of men,
sn3.1:6.2: as aristocrat, will gain the throne.
sn3.1:6.3: And in his anger he’ll execute a royal punishment,
sn3.1:6.6: for the sake of your own life.
sn3.1:7.3: a man should not look down on it
sn3.1:7.4: or despise it for its youth.
sn3.1:8.2: the snake of fiery breath glides along.
sn3.1:8.3: It lashes out and bites the fool,
sn3.1:8.6: for the sake of your own life.
sn3.1:9.1: A fire devours a huge amount,
sn3.1:9.2: a conflagration with a blackened trail.
sn3.1:9.3: A man should not look down on it
sn3.1:10.3: It’ll lash out and burn the fool,
sn3.1:10.6: for the sake of your own life.
sn3.1:11.1: When a forest is burned by fire,
sn3.1:11.2: a conflagration with a blackened trail,
sn3.1:11.3: the shoots will spring up there again,
sn3.1:11.4: with the passing of the days and nights.
sn3.1:12.1: But if a mendicant endowed with ethics
sn3.1:12.3: you’ll have no sons or cattle,
sn3.1:12.4: nor will your heirs find wealth.
sn3.1:13.6: and a mendicant endowed with ethics.”
sn3.1:14.1: When this was said, King Pasenadi of Kosala said to the Buddha,
sn3.1:14.3: As if he were righting the overturned, or revealing the hidden, or pointing out the path to the lost, or lighting a lamp in the dark so people with good eyes can see what’s there, the Buddha has made the teaching clear in many ways.
sn3.1:14.4: I go for refuge to the Buddha, to the teaching, and to the mendicant Saṅgha.
sn3.1:14.5: From this day forth, may the Buddha remember me as a lay follower who has gone for refuge for life.”
